title: Silverchair discography
text:
The discography of <a href="Silverchair">Silverchair</a>, an Australian <a href="alternative%20rock">alternative rock</a> band, consists of five <a href="studio%20album">studio album</a>s, one <a href="extended%20play">extended play</a> (EP), nineteen <a href="single%20%28music%29">singles</a>, one <a href="live%20album">live album</a>, two <a href="compilation%20album">compilation album</a>s, four <a href="VHS%20single">video albums</a>, and twenty <a href="music%20video">music video</a>s.
<a href="Silverchair">Silverchair</a>'s first single, "<a href="Tomorrow%20%28Silverchair%20song%29">Tomorrow</a>", was highly successful upon its Australian release in 1994, and provided the band an opportunity to release their music internationally. Shortly after, they released their debut album; "<a href="Frogstomp">Frogstomp</a>". Achieving success in the United States and performing around the world, Silverchair's band members continued with their school studies, and in 1997 released "<a href="Freak%20Show%20%28album%29">Freak Show</a>". Following the success of 1999's "<a href="Neon%20Ballroom">Neon Ballroom</a>", Silverchair toured worldwide, then announced a break following the termination of their contract with Sony. The band joined , a record label formed by their manager John Watson.
Silverchair returned to recording in June 2001, and released "<a href="Diorama%20%28Silverchair%20album%29">Diorama</a>" in 2002. Lead singer <a href="Daniel%20Johns">Daniel Johns</a> suffered from <a href="reactive%20arthritis">reactive arthritis</a> while the band were touring to promote the album, and after the <a href="ARIA%20Music%20Awards%20of%202002">2002</a> <a href="ARIA%20Awards">ARIA Awards</a> the band announced an indefinite hiatus. Silverchair reunited after <a href="Wave%20Aid">Wave Aid</a> in 2005, and released "<a href="Young%20Modern">Young Modern</a>" in 2007. Silverchair went on an indefinite hiatus in May 2011.
